Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Influence of Tropical Convection on the Evolution and Transport of the Saharan Air Layer
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dust in the atmosphere has important impacts on clouds, precipitation and climate. This is due to how the dust interacts with cloud particles and solar radiation. One of the dustiest places on Earth is the Atlantic Ocean just west of the Sahara Desert. A number of researchers have studied the effect of this "Saharan Air Layer" on tropical cyclones and other cloud systems. However, research under this award will look at the issue in reverse, asking the question: How do clouds and precipitation affect the Saharan Air Layer? The importance of this work is the discovery of how dust is transported and redistributed by clouds and precipitation, which may have a significant impact on climate. The removal of dust from the atmosphere through precipitation may also impact ocean fertilization. In addition, the research will provide training opportunities for the next generation of scientists.

The overall objective of the project is to study how convection impacts the temporal and spatial distributions of dust through cloud processing and transport. The amount of dust and the impacts on the Saharan Air Layer will be assessed through a combination of regional cloud modeling, existing aircraft data sets and existing satellite data sets. The research team poses three main scientific questions that will be addressed in this award: 1) Relative to pre-storm amounts, how much dust is removed from the atmosphere and deposited to the ocean through the action of precipitating storms? 2) Where do convective storms preferentially redistribute dust in the atmosphere, and how is the vertical distribution of dust changed by the passage of convective storms? 3) What are the potential effects of the removal and redistribution of dust on ocean fertilization, and the impacts on direct and indirect radiative effects both locally and downstream of the storm development?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the year, vast quantities of soil-dust particles embedded in the dry Saharan Air Layer travel from Africa westward over the tropical Atlantic Ocean. These particles can act to seed droplets and ice crystals in storms that form over the Atlantic and may develop into hurricanes. Through these microphysical changes, dust particles can influence how strong and deep storms are, how much they rain, how long they last, and how they absorb heat and scatter light. These effects have been shown in prior NSF results by the same collaborative group. The main goal of this new work was to understand the impact of convective storm systems on the redistribution of dust particles in the atmosphere, and the potential importance of this process to subsequent ice nucleation. Our diverse team included researchers experienced in aircraft and satellite data analysis as well as numerical modeling. Training was included for three graduate students who were deeply involved in field work, data analysis, and dissemination of results. Several presentations and publications in major geoscience journals were produced, with a summary of research outcomes given below.

Using aircraft data taken in and around convective storms over the Atlantic, an aerosol enhancement zone was found at the bottom edge of tropical storm anvils. Particle number concentrations in dust size ranges were enhanced by four to sixty times over background concentrations, depending on the storm and particle size. The enhancement zone was also observed in data from the onboard lidar instrument. These measurements were consistent with the approximate amounts of Saharan dust observed in satellite studies and predicted by modeling studies to be lofted by convection (see below). Simple calculations using cloud frequencies obtained from satellite data indicated that lofting of dust by tropical convection may be the primary source of large aerosol particles in the tropical upper troposphere. The above results were used to estimate concentrations of heterogeneous ice nucleating particles lofted by storms to the upper troposphere. A comparison with measured cirrus concentrations showed that lofting of dust is likely important for cirrus formation downstream. 

Numerical simulations included a case study of the 2006 Tropical Storm Debby. The modeling work was unique in its ability to track dust mass throughout the cloud system, from dust regenerated upon hydrometeor evaporation to its removal to the ocean surface. In this simulation, the track and characteristics of the storm were better reproduced when dust particles were included.  It was also shown that some Saharan dust is transported and deposited in the upper troposphere by the storm. Two orders of magnitude more dust was predicted to be deposited to the ocean surface than transported to the upper troposphere, however. A substantial amount of dust was also transported and deposited at middle levels.

Four years of satellite observations were used to assess the influence of tropical storm systems on dust transport over a broad area of the Atlantic Ocean. A novel compositing technique used geostationary cloud observations together with the polar orbiting CloudSat and CALIPSO satellites to track aerosol optical depth changes throughout a typical convective storm lifecycle. It was shown on average that tropical convection accounts for about 15% of dust deposition into the Atlantic Ocean, where it can provide a rapid influx of nutrients for ocean life. Convention also lofts a small amount of dust mass from the Saharan Air Layer to altitudes greater than 6 km. Saharan dust is an efficient ice nucleating particle at cold temperatures and so this is likely important for the formation and lifecycle of clouds downstream of deep convection.

Other particle types in the atmosphere that can efficiently initiate ice formation in clouds are biological particles, such as bacteria and fungi. These particles sometimes co-exist with dust particles, but little is known about their abundance in the atmosphere above ground-level.  New instrumentation based on fluorescence of biological particles was tested on an aircraft to sample these particle types at different altitudes over the U.S. Central Plains, with hands-on training for a graduate student. Number concentrations biological particles usually decreased with height, and generally were about 10-100 L-1 in the continental boundary layer, but were always much lower at temperatures colder than 255K in the free troposphere. At intermediate temperatures where biological ice nucleating particles may influence mixed-phase cloud formation, concentrations of fluorescent particles were the most variable. Predicted vertical distributions of ice nucleating particle concentrations in this temperature regime sometimes reached typical concentrations of primary ice in clouds, but were often much lower. This was the first work to present measured vertical profiles of biological particles at temperatures relevant to ice nucleation in mixed-phase clouds, and quantify their potential effects.

All three types of analysis in our collaborative research--in-situ aircraft measurements, satellite measurements, and modeling--were useful in reaching these important outcomes related to Saharan dust transport and ice nucleation in clouds.
